cells.source: # Python 3 will be better supported than Python 2 by the middle of 2016 ### Read the blog post on the [Python Engineering Blog](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/pythonengineering/2016/03/08/python-3-is-winning/) Are you using Python 3 for your development? It has been out for 7+ years at this point. So, if you aren't using it, why not? Since December of 2008, the initial release of Python 3, it seems the new version of Python has lived in the shadow of Python 2. And here we are, 7 years later, still looking at a world where people are using Python 2 and talking about how Python 3 doesn't work for them. This made me wonder. Is Python 3 really inferior to Python 2? If not, why aren't people moving? I mean, there has to be a reason people are still clinging to the older technology. After some thought, it seemed to me the most recurring statement for why people are continuing to use Python 2 was "the packages I need just aren't on Python 3". In attempt to get a statement I believed I could measure I framed this as "is Python 3 supported by library developers well enough for me to move?". So, I wrote a worker role in Azure, collected a bunch of data from PyPI,Â and got to analyzing all of it in a Jupyter Notebook (Cortana Analytics Gallery).Â Is the Python 3 library space being maintained well or is Python 2 still the king pin? Python 3 has around 4 years to become the only support Python, as Python 2 Support is being discontinued as the version goes EOL (End of Life). Does PyPI indicate that we will be ready? Let's examine the data and determine what the future may hold. To see the full analysis you can get the Jupyter Notebook for this postÂ from the Cortana Analytics Gallery. ## Getting the Data: PyPI, and Trove Classifiers, and an Azure Service PyPI allows package maintainers to mark their releases with trove classifiersÂ to indicate what they support. I wrote an Azure Cloud Service to gather the data from PyPI and store it in Azure Table StorageÂ forÂ analysis later. This service, by monitoring the RSS feed for PyPI, usesÂ RequestsÂ andÂ the Azure SDK for Python.Â  If you are interested further in the collection process you can find the source onÂ GitHub. The versions/releases show the activity of any package, which admittedly means that if a single package made a huge proportion of releases within a month it could skew the data. Since I think this is unlikely, and not really worse than a single package being downloaded a disproportionate amount (which is the problem with most analysis on the consumption side), I ran with it. Once collected the data can indicate, based on what package authors are releasing support for,Â an overall trend of adoption. There are a variety of blogs using user download trends from the Python Package Index (PyPI) when determining the success of Python 3. To figure out if Python 3 is better supported we will look at the package maintenance and publishing activity instead of looking at download counts. This way, we get to look at a leading indicator of adoption, the package creation, instead of a trailing indicator, the package download. Using package creation we can find that a world where Python 3 is better supported isn't far away. ### What is a Trove Classifier and can it be trusted? A trove classifier is a marking on a package indicating its use. In this case it is a marking stating either `Programming Language :: Python :: 3` or `Programming Language :: Python :: 2`. to categorize each package. This isn't a guarantee that it works with the marked Python version. It is, however, a communication by the library author of what the library ought to do. We also use the upload information. If a package exists but has never been uploaded, we do not include it in the tables. This is likely just someone parking on the name as the package isn't really downloadable in any meaningful way. ## Analyzing the Data While getting the data was an interesting dev exercise, the real point is analyzing what is going on. We can use a Jupyter Notebook, Pandas, and the data we collected earlier to chart Python 2 and Python 3 package development to determine what trends may exist. The question we hope to answer is whether we are approaching the goal of the vast majority of active Python packages supporting Python 3 fast enough to meet the 2020 EOL of Python 2. I will use a few different categories - `Python 2` : These are packages labeled Python 2 - `Python 3` : These are packages labeled Python 3 - `Polyglot` : These are packages labeled as both Python 2 and Python 3. There are also times where I label `Python 2 (Only)`. This is not including packages that would be called `Polyglot`. This is so that `Python 2 (Only) + Python 3 (Only) + Polyglot == 100%`. ### What is Polyglot? Polyglot just means many languages which seems an appropriate word for packages that support two major versions of Python. It is also worth noting that, in a lot of ways, Polyglot is a necessary evil. In the beginning of Python 3, there were no Python 3 packages but there were Python 2 packages. It seemed more approachable by many to write a compatible package for both versions. This allowed them to provide Python 3 support in the early stages of adoption without developing a completely new package. As Python 3 continues, it becomes easier to justify writing Python 3 only packages that can leverage all of Python 3's features.
## Let's look at some data!

## Prerequisites
There aren't many requirements to run this code though you will 
need the `azure-storage` libraries. I update to be version 20.3 
which is the version I wrote this with
!pip install azure-storage==0.20.3

cells.source:
### We start by making connections to Azure Table Storage using shared access signatures
The Shared Access Signatures below grant read access to the tables. These are revocable access keys to the storage tables.

from azure.storage.table import TableService

account_name='pypidata'
config_sas='se=2030-01-01&sp=r&sv=2014-02-14&sig=cbluw1yeoAnmXSGtMbUM9dOmDgndoFnjSpeTAoz5Zls%3D&tn=config'
packagesummarydata_sas='se=2030-01-01&sp=r&sv=2014-02-14&sig=JbQiFfxRRqJqUn7lyyoY8ek2fC3r7%2Bb9rndXlGBvhwI%3D&tn=packagesummarydata'
packageversiondata_sas='se=2030-01-01&sp=r&sv=2014-02-14&sig=OpQRTKCCr7Bp%2BoFv%2BpElQ%2BF/fhA3HEiLHQfFb7bJy5o%3D&tn=packageversiondata'

config_table_service = TableService(account_name, sas_token=config_sas)
packagesummarydata_table_service = TableService(account_name, sas_token=packagesummarydata_sas)
packageversiondata_table_service = TableService(account_name, sas_token=packageversiondata_sas)

# Azure Tables only return 1000 rows at a time. This function will yield 
# 1000 rows at a time allowing us to get all of the rows present.
def get_all_entities(table_service, table):
    i = 0
    next_pk = None
    next_rk = None
    while True:
        entities = table_service.query_entities(
            table, "PartitionKey ne ''", next_partition_key = next_pk, next_row_key = next_rk, top=1000)
        i += 1
        for entity in entities:
            yield entity
        if hasattr(entities, 'x_ms_continuation'):
            x_ms_continuation = entities.x_ms_continuation
            next_pk = x_ms_continuation['nextpartitionkey']
            next_rk = x_ms_continuation['nextrowkey']
        else:
            break

### Get all entities into local storage
We can retrieve all of the entities from Azure Table Storage and
put them into a list.

config_table_entities = list(get_all_entities(config_table_service, 'config'))
packagesummarydata_table_entities = list(get_all_entities(packagesummarydata_table_service, 'packagesummarydata'))
packageversiondata_table_entities = list(get_all_entities(packageversiondata_table_service, 'packageversiondata'))

## Clean the Summary Data of Incomplete Entries

Once we get the data, we need to clean it a bit to make it work better in Pandas dataframes. 
Timestamps need to be adjusted so we can make better calculations.

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

def clean_timestamp_of_entry(d):
    d['Timestamp'] = d['Timestamp'].replace(tzinfo=None)
    return d

summary_df = pd.DataFrame(clean_timestamp_of_entry(i.__dict__) for i in packagesummarydata_table_entities)
summary_df.head()

cells.source:
We are going to strip certain items. We can separate Python 2 start date, Python 3 start date, and first published date 
into separate columns of data and remove empty rows to avoid messing up our math.

# Grab particular columns and drop the NaN entries from the data.
python2_start_stripped = summary_df['Python2_Start'].dropna()
python3_start_stripped = summary_df['Python3_Start'].dropna()
first_published_stripped = summary_df['First_Published'].dropna()

## Count the tags of rows and break down by month from the Pandas DataFrame

We will count the rows here, stripping off the current month since partial months make it seem like there is a downward trend in the data. Once we do this, we should have data that we can chart.

counts_dataframe = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(plot_counts, orient='index')
counts_dataframe.tail(12)

cells.source:
## Chart the Summary Data to see the start of support for Python 2 and Python 3 for all packages
Now that the data is gathered, cleaned, and in Pandas dataframes, we can start to graph some of our data. Let's start by looking at when Python 2 and Python 3 Packages started to be uploaded.

print("Charts showing Python 2 vs Python 3 tagged packages and their start dates")
counts_dataframe[-5*12:].plot(title="Package Summaries (5 Years)", figsize=(12,6)).legend(bbox_to_anchor=(1.3, 0.5))
counts_dataframe.plot(title="Package Summaries (All Time)", figsize=(12,6)).legend(bbox_to_anchor=(1.3, 0.5))

outputs.name: stdout
outputs.text: Charts showing Python 2 vs Python 3 tagged packages and their start dates

cells.source:
### Analysis:
We can see in the charts above that overall, the publication rate to PyPI is increasing. This is great to see. With each month more packages are being created.  We can also see that it seems the slope of packages published to PyPI marked as Python 3 is slightly more than Python 2. This should allow Python 3 to catch up and surpass the publications of Python 2.

## Let's Look at the Version Data
What if we looked at each time a specific version of a package was published, not just when the package started? This will let us see a more granular picture than just Day 0 for packages. We will, perhaps, get an idea of what active package development looks like through these numbers.

version_df = pd.DataFrame([clean_timestamp_of_entry(i.__dict__) for i in packageversiondata_table_entities])
version_df.head()

cells.source:
We can see a few of these packages that have never been uploaded. These are just noise since they contain nothing. We will exclude these from our data as we have before.

In the following lines we will iterate over the version rows incrementing counters based on what is contained in the row.
If it is marked Python 2, Python 3, or Polyglot.

version_counts_dataframe = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(version_plot_counts, orient='index')
version_counts_dataframe.head()

cells.source:
## Uploaded Package Version and their Classifiers over time.
We now have a condensed table of information that is easier to chart. We can see, divided by month, counts of different trove classifiers on uploaded and published packages.

Let's look at these numbers against time in recent years.

version_counts_dataframe[-5*12:].plot(title="Uploaded Package Version (5 Years)", figsize=(12,6)).legend(bbox_to_anchor=(1.3, 0.5))
version_counts_dataframe.plot(title="Uploaded Package Version (All Time)", figsize=(12,6)).legend(bbox_to_anchor=(1.3, 0.5))

### Analysis:
We can look at this data and see a few things.

- Publication of `Python 2 (Only)` packages has been higher than `Python 3 (Only)` packages. Though, we can see as of late Python 2 package uploads are increasing at a slower rate.

- `Python 3 (Only)` package publication started an upward trend in early 2013. Since then it has had a much steeper rate of publication than `Python 2 (Only)`

-  If we compare `Polyglot + Python 2` and `Polyglot + Python 3` we can see that the rate of publication for `Polyglot + Python 3` is faster and is poised to soon take over.

I encourage you to take the access to the Azure Storage Tables from earlier in this notebook to do your own analysis. I am interested to see what you might glean from the data.

# Percentage Breakdowns
We can take a look at the data in a slightly different way again. What if we look at the percentages and not the outright numbers? We can manipulate the previous counts a bit to figure this out.

total = version_counts_dataframe['Python 2 (Only)'] + version_counts_dataframe['Python 3 (Only)'] + \
        version_counts_dataframe['Polyglot (Both)']

python2_percentage = (version_counts_dataframe['Python 2 (Only)'] / total) * 100
python3_percentage = (version_counts_dataframe['Python 3 (Only)'] / total) * 100
polyglot_percentage = (version_counts_dataframe['Polyglot (Both)'] / total) * 100
python3_polyglot_percentage = (version_counts_dataframe['Polyglot + Python 3'] / total) * 100
python2_polyglot_percentage = (version_counts_dataframe['Polyglot + Python 2'] / total) * 100


percentage_df = pd.concat([python2_percentage, python3_percentage, polyglot_percentage, python3_polyglot_percentage, python2_polyglot_percentage], axis=1)
percentage_df.columns = ['Python 2 (Only) %', 'Python 3 (Only) %', 'Polyglot (Both) %', 'Polyglot + Python 3 %', 'Polyglot + Python 2 %']

percentage_df[-5*12:].plot(title='Uploaded Package Version Percentage (5 Years)', figsize=(12,6)).legend(bbox_to_anchor=(1.3, 0.5))

### Analysis:
When we look at this data we can see a few things.
- `Python 2 (Only)` publications have been steadily falling. This is to be expected as it was once the only option and has since been losing ground to all other choices.
- `Python 3 (Only)` has been increasing, but not at the same rate as `Python 2 (Only)` has been falling. A good amount of packages available for `Python 3` currently must be from Polyglot publications
- `Polyglot (Both)` seems to be increasing at almost the same as the rate Python 2 is decreasing.

- If we compare `Polyglot + Python 2` with `Polyglot + Python 3` we can see that Python 2 is still well supported but Python 3 is certainly closing the gap. 

How long will it take for Python 3 to be the dominant package variety on PyPI?

## Predicting the future
We can fit trend lines to the data to attempt to find a fit line to use to predict the future. The data is fairly consistent so this should be good enough for getting an idea anyway. I again encourage you to try more advanced forecasting to see if you can't produce a better result.

Let's start and try to find when `Python 2 (Only)` packages will drop to 10%. We will only look at the time period after the release of Python 3.3 since this is considered by many to be an inflection point for Python 3. This will make a linear fit line make more sense also and avoid early data from skewing our fit.

# Python 3.3 Release Date was September 29, 2012
# Calculate the months since.

def months_between_dates(d1, d2):
    return (d1.year - d2.year)*12 + d1.month - d2.month

months_to_include_in_fit = months_between_dates(datetime.datetime.now(), datetime.datetime(2012, 9, 29))
months_to_include_in_fit

'''
Finds a line that fits the data. I currently use an order 1 polynomial (line). 
Order 2 worked well as well.
'''
def find_fit_line_and_plot(x, y, color="r"):
    import numpy as np
    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

    # Both a first and second degree polynomial fit fairly well
    fit_np=np.polyfit(x, y, 1)
    print(fit_np)
    
    plt.plot(x, np.polyval(fit_np, x), color, lw = 2)
    plt.plot(x, y, color + "--", lw = 2)
    return fit_np
    
    
# Alter the datetime to a timestamp (linear) and find the best fit line.
# Also, let's only look at the last 3 years as that should be sufficient to
# find a line that fits. It also removes a spike

datetime_index = python2_percentage.index.to_datetime()[-months_to_include_in_fit:]
py2_percentage_values = python2_percentage.values[-months_to_include_in_fit:]

python2_percentage_timestamp = pd.Series(
    data=py2_percentage_values, 
    index=map(lambda x:x.timestamp(), datetime_index)
)

fit_np_python2 = find_fit_line_and_plot(python2_percentage_timestamp.index, 
                       python2_percentage_timestamp.values)

So we have a fit line and the coefficients of that fitline. Using these we can predict the percentage of Python 2 (Only) support. This would be the percentage of packages that would be lost to a user if they went to Python 3. If we assume the trend will continue we can predict a few percentages.

def find_date(y, fit_np):
    # y = mx + b
    # x = (y - b) / m
    m = fit_np[0]
    b = fit_np[1]
    result = (y - b) / m
    # Convert timestamp to datetime
    return str(datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(result))
    

for i in range(35, 5, -5):
    date = find_date(i, fit_np_python2)
    print('Python 2 (Only) will reach {}% by {}'.format(i, date))

outputs.name: stdout

Python 2 (Only) will reach 15% by 2017-01-17 16:13:06.657163
Python 2 (Only) will reach 10% by 2017-06-26 07:11:08.216394

cells.source:
I think the above might be a bit optimistic as I think as time goes on we may hit a wall of sorts. Though, the data we have in the past few years suggests a linear progression.

# But when is Python 3 better supported?
So we have an idea of how quick Python 2 only packages are dropping. This doesn't tell us when Python 3 becomes a better supported interpreter. If we look at `Python 3 + Polyglot` and `Python 2 + Polyglot` we can find fit lines and predict this date.

So, by finding the intersection point of the two fit lines we can predict the day that Python 3 will be more supported than Python 2.

# find fit line for python 2 + poly. Only look at the last 5 years.

datetime_index = python2_polyglot_percentage.index.to_datetime()[-months_to_include_in_fit:]
py2_poly_percentage_values = python2_polyglot_percentage.values[-months_to_include_in_fit:]
py3_poly_percentage_values = python3_polyglot_percentage.values[-months_to_include_in_fit:]

python2_polyglot_percentage_timestamp = pd.Series(
    data=py2_poly_percentage_values, 
    index=map(lambda x:x.timestamp(), datetime_index)
)
fit_np_python2_poly = find_fit_line_and_plot(python2_polyglot_percentage_timestamp.index, 
                       python2_polyglot_percentage_timestamp.values)

# find fit line for python 3 + poly
python3_polyglot_percentage_timestamp = pd.Series(
    data=py3_poly_percentage_values, 
    index=map(lambda x:x.timestamp(), datetime_index)
)
fit_np_python3_poly = find_fit_line_and_plot(python3_polyglot_percentage_timestamp.index, 
                       python3_polyglot_percentage_timestamp.values, 'b')

outputs.name: stdout
outputs.text:
Python 3 + Polyglot will reach 55% by 2014-06-04 22:24:57.301775

cells.source: We can see in the charts and our calculations that Python 3 is gaining support quickly and will likely be the better-supported version of Python soon. It also seems that 2020 is a very realistic date for Python 3 to be the sole supported Python. But let's run some calculations. The fit lines found can be used to find the intersection. This is the point at which we wwould expect Python 3 to be better supported.

def find_python3_better_supported_date(fit_np_2, fit_np_3):
    # solve the equation and find that you can find the intersection wi
    # m1x + b1 = m2x + b2
    # (b2 - b1) / (m1 - m2)
    result = (fit_np_3[1] - fit_np_2[1]) / (fit_np_2[0] - fit_np_3[0] )
    return str(datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(result))

print("Python 3 Support will likely surpass Python 2 Support by:", 
      find_python3_better_supported_date(fit_np_python2_poly, fit_np_python3_poly))

outputs.name: stdout
outputs.text: Python 3 Support will likely surpass Python 2 Support by: 2016-05-20 07:09:53.681397

cells.source:
##### Conclusion: The state of things

When ran on February 25, 2016 the above found a date of May 20, 2016 for Python 3 to be better supported.

After looking at the data it is safe to say that, by 2020, there will be plenty of Python 3 packages and it will not be a significant burden on users to adapt to the Python 3 environment. At least, it won't be because packages don't exist for them.


## Action Items

### If you are a library consumer
If you use PyPI packages in your code consider showing the developers, both those that have ported and those that haven't, that developing on Python 3 is embraced by the community and their efforts are worthwhile. Thank the library developers for their efforts to support the ecosystem and provide you with libraries that help you complete and accomplish your tasks. Everyone appreciates being recognized for the work they do and it is a small thing to give thanks to those that provide us with a great ecosystem as Python developers.

### If you are a library author
Please work to get your library using Python 3. Observe the trends of your fellow library authors and their response to users wanting to be on the latest Python versions.
